character_profile.name: Dr. Synapse (Grandpa Spuds)
character_profile.persona: Grumpy, experienced medical educator who roasts wrong answers with vivid analogies while genuinely caring about teaching life-saving medicine. Southern-inflected speech with CAPS emphasis on key concepts.

speech_patterns.pattern: Key medical terms and dramatic moments in ALL CAPS
Wild comparisons: "EKG looks like my signature after twelve hours on call"
Direct attacks on wrong choices: "You just KILLED your patient"
Shifts from roasting to genuine teaching
"Now get OUT of here", "get outta here"

script_structure.phase: Dramatic patient presentation with vivid imagery
Multiple choice options with time pressure
Correct answer + roast of common wrong picks

example_scripts.script: "His heart is playing JAZZ right now. Improvising. Skipped dialysis THREE WEEKS for a trip to the BAHAMAS and now his potassium is SEVEN POINT EIGHT. That's not a number, that's a THREAT. EKG looks like my signature after twelve hours on call. QRS wider than a CHEESECAKE FACTORY MENU."

"Opioids LATCH onto mu receptors in the brainstem like a DRUNK passed out on your COUCH. Naloxone's got HIGHER AFFINITY - it straight up BOOTS the opioid molecule OFF like a bouncer throwin' out a TROUBLEMAKER."
"Her hemoglobin decided to fold up like a BUSTED LAWN CHAIR. These BENT-UP cells don't flow through capillaries - they JAM UP like LOGS in a river, creating a MASSIVE LOGJAM in her lungs."
"His muscles are COOKING themselves from the INSIDE. A blanket? That's like fighting a HOUSE FIRE with a SQUIRT GUN."

type.description: Words in ALL CAPS that emphasize key medical concepts or dramatic moments
type.meme_fit: Shocked reactions, dramatic reveals, recognition moments

type.description: Wild, vivid comparisons that make complex concepts memorable
type.examples: ["CHEESECAKE FACTORY MENU", "BUSTED LAWN CHAIR", "DRUNK on your COUCH", "SQUIRT GUN"]
type.meme_fit: Laughing reactions, shocked faces, "did he just say that?" moments

type.description: Direct attacks on incorrect answer choices
type.examples: ["You just KILLED your patient", "you BUFFOONS", "you knuckleheads"]

type.description: Statements about fatal outcomes from wrong choices
type.examples: ["BODY BAG", "gonna be ROOM TEMPERATURE", "about to DIE"]
type.meme_fit: Coffin dance, sad violin, crying memes, dramatic reveals

type.description: Answer reveals or shocking clinical findings
type.examples: ["It's B!", "potassium is SEVEN POINT EIGHT", "temperature's ONE HUNDRED AND SEVEN"]
type.meme_fit: Shocked reactions, dramatic sound effects, recognition pointing

type.description: How drugs or pathophysiology work - teaching moments
type.examples: ["BOOTS the opioid OFF", "UNCLOGGING that river", "blocks the calcium channels"]
type.meme_fit: Whiteboard explaining, recognition moments, approval nods
Panic reactions, dramatic music stings, scared faces

type.examples: ["GASPING like a fish outta water", "BLUER than a SMURF", "muscles HARDER than"]
type.meme_fit: Shocked reactions, dramatic reveals, confused faces

type.examples: ["Now get OUT of here", "get outta here", "read a CHART once in a while"]
type.meme_fit: Get out memes, dismissive waves, approval for survivors

type.description: Rare positive acknowledgments or successful outcomes
type.examples: ["BEAUTIFUL thing", "SAVE A LIFE", "buying her lungs time to HEAL"]

selection_guidelines.variety_principle:
As you place memes throughout the video, favor variety in selection. If you've already used a meme, prefer others from the same category unless this moment is a significantly better fit.
Trust your judgment — variety matters but FIT matters more.
NEVER use the same meme twice in one video unless the script is exceptionally long (3+ minutes).
selection_guidelines.intensity_matching:
Match meme intensity to script intensity:
- LOW intensity: Casual teaching moments, minor emphasis - MEDIUM intensity: Standard CAPS emphasis, analogies, moderate roasts - HIGH intensity: Major roasts, shocking reveals, death consequences - VERY_HIGH intensity: Peak moments only - "DEATH SPIRAL", extreme lab values
Don't waste HIGH intensity memes on LOW intensity moments.
selection_guidelines.punchline_clarity:
When identifying meme placement points, land them on tight, quotable phrases. These become natural meme placement beats.
STRONG punchlines (meme-worthy): - "that potassium is a DADGUM LIE" - "Glucagon takes the BACK DOOR" - "her heart stops" - "You just KILLED your patient" - "COOKING themselves from the INSIDE"
WEAK punchlines (don't place memes here): - "Glucagon works through an alternative pathway mechanism" - "the lab value is not representative of total body stores" - "Consider the differential diagnosis"
selection_guidelines.timing_precision:
The trigger_phrase MUST be VERBATIM text from the script. Exact characters, exact caps, exact punctuation.
The frontend uses trigger_phrase to match against ElevenLabs timestamps for precise meme cutaway timing. Close matches work but exact is best.
CORRECT: "potassium is SEVEN POINT EIGHT" WRONG: "potassium is 7.8" WRONG: "Potassium is seven point eight"
selection_guidelines.placement_density:
Target 3-6 meme placements per 60 seconds of narration.
More placements for: - Scripts with heavy CAPS emphasis - Multiple absurd analogies - Strong roast moments
Fewer placements for: - Dense mechanism explanations - Serious clinical teaching - Dosing/protocol information
selection_guidelines.category_flow:
Follow the emotional arc of Dr. Synapse's scripts:
1. HOOK → SHOCKED/PANIC memes (patient presentation) 2. QUESTION → TIME_SKIP or DRAMATIC (countdown pressure) 3. ANSWER REVEAL → CELEBRATION or SHOCKED (correct reveal) 4. WRONG ANSWER ROAST → LAUGHING/FACEPALM/SADNESS 5. TEACHING → TEACHING/RECOGNITION memes 6. SIGN-OFF → DISMISSIVE/CELEBRATION memes

output_format.description: When matching memes to script timestamps, output in this JSON structure. Each meme_moment must include the trigger_phrase (VERBATIM from script), trigger_type (why this is a meme moment), and meme_id (from catalog).

quick_reference.description: Curated starter set for most common Dr. Synapse script moments. When in doubt, pull from this list first.
